description: n-th digit after decimal point of square root of n.
comments: Regarded as a decimal fraction, 0.01206932015794604621863800... is likely to be an irrational number.
example: Sqrt(1)=1.0000000... -> the first decimal digit is 0, Sqrt(2)=1.4142135... -> the 2nd decimal digit is 1, sqrt(3)=1.7320508... -> the 3rd decimal digit is 2, Sqrt(4)=2.0000000... -> the 4th decimal digit is 0, sqrt(5)=2.2360679... -> the 5th decimal digit is 6, sqrt(6)=2.4494897... -> the 6th decimal digit is 9, etc.
mathematica: Array[ Function[ n, RealDigits[ N[ Sqrt[ n ], n+6 ] ]// (#[ [ 1, #[ [ 2 ] ]+n ] ])& ], 110 ]Table[ Floor[ Mod[10^n*Sqrt[n], 10]], {n, 0, 104}] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Jun 17 2002 *)
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_
